Many people have prognosticated the future, some too optimistically and some too pessimistically. Those who have predicted the future, people of many other professions and fields of expertise, believe that humanity will usher in new-found technological prosperity, become crippled by financial and social ruin, or somewhere in between. Unfortunately, though, with all of the predictions written about the future, very few have come true except for those who kept their predictions vague enough to allow for as many possibilities as possible.Michio Kaku’s new book Physics of the Future: How Science Will Shape Human Destiny and our Daily Lives by the Year 2100 is one more work among others that have aimed to foretell the future. Utilizing current research, expert opinion from the world’s top three-hundred researchers, scientists, and inventors, and his personal experiences with upcoming technologies, Kaku wrote Physics of the Future to describe the many possible scientific achievements of the twenty-first century and how they will impact humanity in the immediate future (Present – 2030), mid-future (2030 – 2070), and far future (2070-2100). Physics of the Future is a well-written text that suffers from inaccuracies in its predictions, mostly because he cannot predict with detail tomorrow. But it instead garners a riveting passion and love for the sciences that stays with readers for many years.Physics of the Future is easy to read. Additionally, it is also a quick read inasmuch as lower levels of diction allows for audiences to quickly grasp the messages that Kaku presents in his book. One can quickly read through his book, absorbing the implications of the book’s content in a week. The book is also well-organized, therefore providing natural breaks for readers. The first chapter is the prologue Kaku utilizes to introduce the subject matter of his book while simultaneously explaining how others who have attempted to predict the future were usually flawed in their predictions. Using this fact, and without providing adequate support for this claim, Kaku goes on in the prologue to bolster up his ethos by explaining that his book is as accurate as possible because the visions foretold in the book come from scientists, those actually doing the research, than those not engaging in the sciences and simply charting tomorrow’s future. From here, a majority of the book is divided into different categories, each chapter explicating a future for a specific set of technologies; this is divided into three predominant sections (although these sections also have many more sub-sections): Near Future (Present – 2030), Mid-Future (2030 – 2070), Far Future (2070 – 2100). The second-to-last chapter does not follow this format, allowing Kaku to reiterate the fact that humanity together decides its fatum. The last chapter is unique, summarily providing readers with a narrative that serves as a recap of the book. The chapters and sections are brief, allowing readers to take breaks as necessary in finishing the book. This organization also assists readers by making Kaku’s points obvious and quick to understand.Physics of the Future, with its readability, shares the problems its predecessors encountered as they expressed their visions of tomorrow. The arguments are based on assumptions. For example, Kaku posits that humanity will discover a material besides silicon to power computers insofar as Moore’s Law will soon no longer apply to computing power between 2020 and 2030. (Every two years, the computing power of computers double as transistors become increasingly smaller.) Kaku presents many future alternatives—quantum computing, atomic transistors—to counter the problem. Although this is vague, Kaku denies the other possibility: Humanity may not discover alternatives to silicon computing. Kaku does not address this concern, nor does he address a picture of the future where technological solutions are nowhere found to redress current social problems. Other incidents similar to this one throughout Physics of the Future wreck Kaku’s ethos although he is a well-known physicist, author of other books like Parallel Worlds and Visions, and host of manifold multifarious TV science specials and documentaries for different stations like Discovery Channel and Science Channel.Despite these pitfalls in Kaku’s arguments, his optimism about the subject radiates on every page. Perusing his book kindles an interest for science and societal advancement. Readers are drawn into the fire of scientific discovery, invited to question why they are not living with these promising technologies. In an almost utopian world that Kaku proposes for tomorrow, readers are attracted to ride on the backs of extinct dinosaurs, to soar the skies, to take that trip to the beach and relax directly from one’s own home virtually. Readers will wonder why the United States extinguished the flames of space exploration, the ideas of sending robots to the Moon and establishing outposts on Mars and nearby asteroids. In addition to all of the aforementioned questions readers will possibly have in perusing Physics of the Future, readers will question why life-robbing diseases like cancer have not yet been cured. Kaku does a satisfactory job of describing medicine’s implications and technological advancements in the future, but constantly brings up cancer. In the future, Kaku promises that President Nixon’s spirit and ambitions will finally rest insofar as his War on Cancer, declared in 1971, will be over—finally, a majority of diseases will be treatable. This is fortunate for cancer victims, cancer survivors, and their families; however, it weakens Kaku’s validity in his arguments as other diseases like heart disease are not given as much attention. Centralizing portions of the book around eradicating cancer also leads Kaku into making unsupported overgeneralizations like that of cancer “disappearing from the English language.” Making this overgeneralization and others similar to it only exploits an almost near-ignorance to admit that the cure for cancer may be insurmountable and may never be palpable for mass commercialization, degrading the argument for a future, a future of human prosperity. Kaku’s optimism about the future is double-sided. His optimism can encourage one to salivate at tomorrow’s promises and embrace them, but can also lead to ignorance in admitting the negative uncertainties of tomorrow by not answering the claims that it may be impossible to find a cure for cancer, or that it may be impossible to replace silicon computing. The dearth of validity in Kaku’s arguments may make readers not peruse the book, but one other attribute of the book lies in its value. Books that have foretold the future may depict the palpable realms of tomorrow like Raymond Kurzweil’s The Singularity is Near and Steve Kelly’s What Technology Wants, and in fiction books like Edward Bellamy’s Looking Backward, Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World, and George Orwell’s 1984, but they do not necessarily empower humanity to chase after those visions.Kaku does. Constantly reminding readers of how humanity can control the civilization it builds, he utilizes the second-to-last chapter of his book, “The Future of Humanity,” to reiterate this point. People are the ends to themselves, i.e., people are in control of where they wish to be. This very principle violates the predictions Kaku foretells insofar as certain technological advancements can come sooner or later than when he says they will; devaluing the dates for which these technological marvels will impact people is how this book should be read. For Kaku’s vision is not necessarily founded on those dates. Rather, it is founded by the scientists, and more importantly, the people who choose whether to categorize science as first or last in their priorities for the near future.Michio Kaku’s Physics of the Future is readable, structured, optimistic, one-sided, and empowering. Indeed, many audiences would come to enjoy the book’s value and its purpose. However, the book is more suitable for two categories of people. The first category is people who are enthusiastic about the future, who rivet in excitement whenever one begins to speak of the possibilities for tomorrow’s culture, economy, polity, et alia. The second category of people, though, is more promising: Students currently enrolled in high school. This book is not necessarily suited in providing students a background into each of the technologies presented, but it does excellently in providing incentive to students. Physics of the Future is broad and covers extensive technologies, occasionally explicating on certain scientific processes for which some of the technologies operate. In turn, this may influence students, making them curious about how scientists are going about and making these technologies possible. The book presents briefly the problems that are conquering this current day and age, but motivates students to become more cognizant about them and more responsive to the progresses and hindrances held to addressing problems like poverty and global warming. Finally, Kaku’s optimism allows for hope as college-bound seniors and upcoming grades of students sail forward into the world, whether their destination lies in four-year universities, the military, or wherever else they may land up. These students will have to deal with tomorrow’s uncertainties, and there will be times in which they will not want to go forward with their dreams, but Kaku’s Physics of the Future is enough to give students another chance, to abet students to craft a future for which they will be satisfied with. A future they and the rest of humanity can live with.

Physics of the Future is your standard ‘what will the world be like in 100 years?’ book of prognostications. Physicist and science popularizer Michio Kaku structures the book into three timeframes … the near future (up to 2030), mid-century (2030 – 2070) and beyond (2070 – 2100). He then looks at advances that will occur in a number of scientific and engineering domains (for example: robotics, medicine, artificial intelligence, computing, etc.) and describes potential advances in each based upon the current state and direction of research. Kaku is a techno-utopian, and as such, the book is pretty much exactly what you would expect. The human lifespan will be extended, robots will become ubiquitous, computers will become intelligent, poverty will be eliminated, our children will be genetically engineered to be disease free, fossil fuels will be a thing of the past, we’ll set up colonies on the moon and mars and we’ll all live happy, healthy, fulfilling lives in our shiny unisex jumpsuits. On the positive side, Kaku is familiar with the state of the technology in each of the areas he discusses. Thus his predictions begin by extending the current state of today’s research after assuming that it winds up being technologically viable, scalable, cost effective and adopted into broad public use. He then lets his imagination run wild as to the marvels we’ll achieve by the end of the century. Unfortunately, his imagination is pretty much based on what other people have written because everything he predicts is pretty much stuff I’d heard before (except for the idea of downloading software that would allow you to re-program the nanobots that make up every item of our homes, allowing one to reconfigure and redecorate the entire house at the push of a button). On the negative side, people are terrible at predicting the future, so there’s no reason to think any of his predictions will come true. But, one thing that we can be sure of is that every advance will have negative, unforeseen consequences and Kaku ignores these almost entirely (except in instances where he goes out of his way to poo-poo the naysayers). But he’s ignoring history:-	The combustion engine dramatically increased the amount of work a person could perform. It also brought about the existential threat of global warming. -	Splitting the atom was supposed to have brought unlimited free energy. It also gave us Chernobyl and the atomic bomb. -	The internet was supposed to have resulted in the democratization and proliferation of knowledge. Yet the proliferation of bullshit has been a notable achievement.To describe the miraculous advances in medicine that gene editing will bring while ignoring the threat of bio-engineered bacteria and viruses is illustrative of a blind spot that appears to be the defining characteristic of those who fall within the techno-utopian camp. Just imagine someone hacking the reconfigurable home described above … what do you think they would do? If you don’t believe they’d turn your living room into a lagoon of human waste as a practical joke, then you don’t understand human psychology (or toilet humor). The other thing that annoys me about these idealistic prognosticators of a utopian future is that there is rarely a place in their vision for the natural world (beyond the unimaginative proposal of bringing back extinct species). For them, the future is one that is entirely man-made with humans living in an artificial environment of their own construction. But this ignores another aspect of human psychology, our love of nature. Biologist E.O. Wilson calls this biophilia – the idea that humans possess an innate tendency to seek connections with nature and other forms of life. Perhaps these futurists believe we’ll simply genetically engineer this trait out of existence, but I think a more likely explanation is that, while they may have a decent understanding of technology, their understanding of human nature leaves something to be desired.

In his Introduction to Physics of the Future, Michio Kaku states that there were two experiences during his childhood that have defined his life and shaped his career. The first was hearing about the death of Albert Einstein and the fact that the world’s greatest scientist had died before being able to complete his most important work [his ‘theory of everything’]. The second of these critical experiences was his regular Saturday morning viewing of fantastical television shows such as Flash Gordon. These certainly sound like the formative experiences of someone who would look to the future of science in both a critical and imaginative way.Importantly though, Michio Kaku is more than just a dreamer; even in his youth he was an exceptional scientist and inventor. While still in high school Kaku built a 2.3-million electron volt particle accelerator in his parent’s garage. Previously he had built a cloud chamber with a powerful magnetic field and photographed tracks of antimatter. He certainly seems like the kind of person whose scientific ideas you can trust.Its credentials thus established, Physics of the Future considers what will have changed in the world by the year 2100 in several key categories: computing, artificial intelligence, medicine, nanotechnology, energy, space travel, wealth and humanity. Each category is considered in a new chapter, with the chapters being broken down into innovations which will occur in the near future, those which should happen in the mid-century, and those which we will have to wait until the far future for. This structure is very helpful in demonstrating the progression of science and technology and so also serves to make the various predictions seem more achievable.While some of Kaku’s predictions for the future seem certain and very much achievable given the current state of technology [faster internet, TV walls, self-driving cars etc], some of the things that he foresees being developed in the next ninety or so years are really quite extraordinary. It’s amazing to think that scientists are within striking distance of spaceships powered by laser propulsion and sensors [or nanobots] in clothing that can scan DNA and diagnose illnesses. A great deal of Physics of the Future is, perhaps unsurprisingly, concerned with matters that still seem to be within the realm of science fiction. This is not to say that the evidence and arguments presented by Kaku are unlikely, just to emphasise how extraordinarily quickly developments seem to be being made.The world envisioned by Michio Kaku in Physics of the Future is both amazing and realistic. Kaku has a very clear writing style and is able to explain complex subjects in a way that is straightforward and engaging to the layman. His delivery as well as the mind-bogglingly interesting subject matter ensures that Physics of the Future is an absorbing read from the very beginning. While some of the prospective innovations will be familiar to readers of some of Kaku’s other books [Physics of the Impossible, Parallel Worlds], the majority of the material is new and any repartition that does exist is necessary in order to build a complete picture of the area under discussion.Physics of the Future is a fascinating and enlightening book. The future breakthroughs being discussed by Kaku are amazing, not least because they seem so likely to occur in the [relatively] near future. Additionally, the insight that Kaku provides into innovative and life-changing scientific work that is currently being carried out but that is perhaps not receiving the publicity that its importance should justify is also both important and illuminating. The future looks likely to be a very exciting [if germ conscious] place.

Physics of the Future by Michio Kaku is an extremely interesting book about scientific predictions of the future’s technology. What I particularly like about this book is that, unlike a lot of other futurist books, Physics of the Future explains the science that would make future technology possible. The book makes predictions for the next few years, a few decades into the future, and for the year 2100. The first chapter (“Future of the Computer”) is about how, in the future, computers will need a new kind of technology. Now, Moore’s Law states that computers get faster every year. However, at some point, it will be physically impossible to create faster computers using silicon. Then, a totally new way of making computers (without silicon) will be needed. The second chapter (“Future of AI”) is about how artificial intelligence will improve in the future. As with the rest of the book, Michio Kaku describes many different AI robots of today that could evolve into future robots. For instance, the Honda Asimo is a child-sized humanoid robot that can act in a life-like way (but has no intelligence). What I particularly enjoy about this chapter is that, unlike movies/other books about the future, Michio Kaku doesn’t assume that robots will become conscious and take over the world. Mr. Kaku’s realistic theory is that robots will slowly get more and more intelligent, but will be programmed to NOT attack people. The third chapter (“Future of Medicine”) is about how, in the future, medicine will do magical things. Michio Kaku sites research about genes that could be manipulated for longevity, discusses how ‘nanoparticles’ (molecule-sized ‘robots’ that are made of chemicals but can go through the body to do specific tasks) will be used to attack diseases, and even mentions how it may be possible to grow custom organs. The central idea of this chapter is that analyzing DNA will help manipulate life in new ways (like manipulating human genes using genetically modified viruses to remove hereditary diseases). The fourth chapter (“Nanotechnology”) is about how machines/chemicals made of a few atoms and too small to see will become useful for tasks such as detecting cancer and entering the body. The fifth chapter (“Future of Energy”) is about different ways in which humanity will have to survive without fossil fuels. In this chapter, the author writes about various experimental nuclear fusion reactors that exist today. In chapter six (“Future of Space Travel”), Michio Kaku makes predictions that range from semi-manned moon bases to interplanetary colonies. Chapters seven and eight are extremely important, as they detail, using evidence from history, how money will move in the future. It is predicted that robots will take repetitive jobs and technology will define who has money. What I find interesting about these chapters is that Michio Kaku uses trends from history to predict the future. While chapter seven is mostly about money, chapter eight discusses how people will make what the author calls a “planetary civilization.” The very last chapter is absolutely my favorite. It’s a story of one ordinary man’s day, living in 2100. He owns a levitating car (it uses superconductors to hover), has many organs that were specially grown for him after an accident, and works for a robot firm.Here's a quote from that chapter:Leaving the bathroom, you wrap some wires around your head, which allow you to telepathically control your home: you mentally raise the temperature of the apartment, turn on some soothing music, tell the robotic cook in your kitchen to make breakfast and brew some coffee, and order your magnetic car to leave the garage and be ready to pick you up ... While drinking hot coffee, you start scanning the headlines that flash in your contact lenses.- The outpost on Mars is requesting more supplies. Winter on Mars is fast approaching. If the settlers are going to complete the next stage in colonization, they need more resources from earth to handle the freezing-cold weather. The plan is to start the first phase of terraforming Mars by raising its surface temperature.- The first starships are ready for launch. Millions of nanobots, each about the size of a pinhead, will be fired from the moon base, whip around Jupiter using its magnetic field, and head off to a nearby star. It will take years, however, before a handful of these nanobots reach their destination in another star system.- Yet another extinct animal is going to join the local zoo. This time, it's a rare saber-toothed tiget, brought back via DNA find frozen in the tundra. Because the earth has been heating up, DNA from more and more extinct animals has been recovered and then cloned to fill zoos around the world.(Physics of the Future by Michio Kaku, page 409)This quote summarizes many important topics from the book - using technologies like fMRI scans to get rudimentary readings of thoughts, using miniature, mass-produced nanobots to explore the universe, and doing medicine that involves DNA (such as cloning).This book makes me think of social issues because I’ll be living in part of what this book describes. The book notes the social issues of terrorism and nuclear war.There are groups, however, that instinctively resist the trend toward a Type I planetary civilization, because they know that it is progressive, free, scientific, prosperous, and educated. These forces may not be conscious of this fact and cannot articulate it, but they are in effect struggling against the trend toward a Type I [meaning global] civilization.Michio Kaku writes that, to become a “planetary civilization,” countries must resolve differences. In a “planetary civilization,” countries will apparently intermingle more freely. In addition, Mr. Kaku puts current world affairs into the bigger picture of where civilization is heading (like in the above quote). I like the part of the book that postulates that robots won’t take over the world, because it’s actually realistic. Having seen robots (and programmed them), I know that even making a vacuum cleaner robot with no intelligence is quite hard (Roomba vacuums must get into all the corners, not break things, get out of tight spaces, and still be easy to control). Considering that Siri has no emotions and can only do exactly what it is asked to, the idea of a robot overlord is ridiculous. The following quote from the last chapter, "A Day in the Life in 2100," shows how unintelligent robots are (the person described is buying a robot dog to give to his nephew). You look over the latest robot dogs. Amazing what these pet robots can do, you say to yourself. They can play, run, fetch, do anything a dog can do. Everything but pee on the carpet. Maybe that's why parents buy them for their kids, you muse.Then you say to the robot clerk, "I'm buying a robot pet for my six-year-old nephew. He's a very intelligent, hands-on type of kid. But he's also sometimes shy and quiet. What kind of dog might help bring him out of his shell?"The robot replies, "I am sorry, sir. That is outside my programming. Perhaps I can interest you in a space toy?"You forgot that robots, no matter how versatile, have a long way to go before they understand human behavior.If I could speak with Michio Kaku, I would ask him whether he thinks that society will accept the idea of manipulating genes for any purpose. The book does discuss how manipulating genes may or may not be moral, but only says that genetically engineering something like intelligence will be extremely hard to do. The setting of this nonfiction is important because, unlike a lot of books about the future, a lot of the information is set in labs that exist today. Michio Kaku takes a cutting edge lab or experiment that exists now, then shows how it may continue in the future. Lastly, the last time that I read this book was quite a while ago. At that time, I didn’t know much world history and didn’t really understand world affairs. Now, reading the book again, I can fully understand more of the points in the chapter on the future of civilization. This is a book with enough information to last many re-readings, but it still uses understandable language.

Huge changes are coming to our world soon.They’re going to affect your health, wealth, and job. They’re going to take us back into space and make us live longer. They are changes that almost blow the mind. And they’ve already begun.Michio Kaku is a world-renowned physicist that has always been fascinated with all sorts of science. And in Physics of the Future, he looks at what’s currently happening in computing, robotics, biotechnology, medicine, energy, and engineering, and explains how it’s going to affect our daily life between now and 2030, 2030 to 2070, and 2070 to 2100.The insights are awesome. The book’s a feast. Page after page.Did you know, for example, that there are parts of our DNA that have genes for certain traits, but those genes are turned off? For example, humans have genes for growing fur all over our bodies, but they’re turned off. Snakes have genes for legs that have been turned off. Chickens, one of the distant progeny of the dinosaurs, have genes for growing tooth buds in their beaks (imagine the grandchildren being chased by one of those bad boys). There are many more such dormant genes, and in the not too distant future, we’ll be able to turn them on.Did you know that today we can regrow organs? So far scientists can grow skin, blood, blood vessels, heart valves, cartilage, bone, noses, and ears from your own cells. They’ve be able to grow windpipes and bladders. Imagine damaging your eye and being able to grow a new one that your body won’t reject.Did you know that we’ve already been able to hook people up so they can move objects with their minds?And what about computers and robots? Many futurists fear the robots will become smarter than us and take over the world. Will they? Kaku explains why this isn’t likely with the technology we currently have and what really makes up intelligence.These are just a couple of the dozens of thrilling topics Kaku explores. And he makes it all so easy to understand and entertaining.A new world is coming, full of perils and exciting opportunities. An Kaku gives us an intelligent sneak peek.If you wonder what our world will be like in the near future, if you enjoy science and technology, if you want to be informed, then you will love this book. When you finish it, you can then move onto his book The Future of Humanity, which delves deeper into what we can expect in the near future in space. You can then move to The Future of the Mind, in which he explores in more detail what we can expect in understanding, enhancing, and empowering our minds.

Here's another example of assumption gone wrong. I knew that Physics of the Future originally released several years ago, but I assumed that it was updated recently and I love Michio Kaku. So, I blinded borrowed the audio CDs from the library, ripped the discs, and transferred to my phone. This should have been my first indication that this isn't updated...To be fair, maybe the topics in Physics of the Future were new and fascinating upon release, but science moves fast. Being a casual follower of sciencey stuff, I didn't get much from this book. One thing that I DID find revelatory is Kaku's hypothesis that financial booms and busts follow technology booms. He didn't say that tech causes financial busts, but there definitely is some correlation.Sadly, I don't think that I can really recommend this book, unless the publisher releases an updated version. If you're new to following tech and science, this could be a good book to start. But, go in knowing that some of the projections that Kaku made are off (self driving car tech, automation, gene editing) and that some of the advancements mentioned are fairly common now. Also be prepared for a big section of the book dedicated to climate change. Not that this is bad, but too much time was spent discussing this. (YES climate change is real - whether it's caused by us humans or part of Earth's climatic cycle - it's real and it's going to cause serious trouble - especially if we don't try to do something about it)This reminds me of another gripe: rambling. Kaku got a little too rambley in some bits. Too much exposition. Too much irrelevant information. Much like this review...

To be honest, I was expecting much more from this book nevertheless it informed me on the things I had interest in and enlightened me on some stuff which I had had no idea of. (I think the reason of disappointment lies in the title. It gives you a vision of what the future might look like and does it on the basis of the current works in physics, astronomy, space, etc. and also by looking at education, history and human nature - not merely "physics". That word leads one to a wrong anticipation. I, for example, was anticipating more depth of concepts in physics) Whatever. Let's reflect some thoughts. It starts with a fictional utopia fantasy but if you keep going on you'll see it's not completely fairytale-ish. It debates war, illnesses, mistakes, and so forth. But even the utopic ideas cannot be deemed as a fiction novel since the writer builds it according to the works that going on in the labs and in related fields. Yet, no one can point where the lief goes. But it's gratitude-worthy for letting us know what people try to create in those fields.It was bizarre to always read the same movie references, I'd prefer more diverse examples. Also, a yearning for a 'mythological type of God-like human'? Sorry, it was funny.There were good facts about human nature, the dark sides in our history and even in the moment. It was just and brave. Moreover, some facts make you realize how things developed and makes you brainstorm how will they develop from now on.So my conclusion is, the writer is obviously in possession of significant knowledge and vision however, being an author is another thing. It's like, you can know how magicians trick but putting a show requires other talents. Also shoutout to the Turkish translators, this was the best translated book I have ever read!

Physics of the Future, while bringing up some generally good ideas about possible technologies of the future, fails in its methods of describing and supporting possible new ideas. The book is organized into sections, each one describing past predictions, current technologies, and Kaku's opinion of what the section's field will look like in future years. The description of past predictions, while not nessacarily needing to be as long as it is, does bring up some interesting points and provides insight on how wrong the rest of the book will be. Physics of the Future was published in 2011, and as of 2019 is already just as correct as Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey was at predicting future technologies. Kaku predicts that "[all] four walls of your living room will have wall screens, so you will be surrounded by images of your relatives from far away" (22) and that a "mighty mouse gene" that "increases [...] muscle mass so that [a] mouse appears to be musclebound" (79) will be spliced into the human genome. Obviously, the reality of either statement is laughable now, with VR headsets becoming more mainstream and CRISPR not being the miracle system capable of seamlessly editing DNA that it was thought to be 2011. Kaku opened his book promising not to "[underestimete] the pace of technological progress" (11) and in doing so wrote lengthily on any whisper of a breakthrough. The best way to describe Physics of the Future would be as a transcribed conversation about future technology with somebody who has no experience in the field and whose knowledge of current research is what they see in sci-fi movies.

Forecasting is a difficult task. It is far more difficult when the forecaster is trying to predict the likely developments in an exponentially changing field like scientific and technological progress. What makes it worse for the book is that someone is reviewing it many years after the publication.For any future reader of Prof Kaku’s 2011 work from now on (2019), the most interesting aspects are his long-term forecasts - ie, what he expects to see beyond 2050. Some of his absolute near-term predictions have come to a pass, while some macro trends seem to have shifted within AI, biotech and data sciences at least. Prof Kaku has no major over-arching theme, like singularity, climate-led doom, or endless life and prosperity for all - like in many other seminal pieces on these subjects. All these themes and many more are covered in the book perfunctorily. In Prof Kaku’s future, none of these themes will lord over everything while all of them will remain nearly equally valid/invalid as new products, connectivities, body extensions, ways of living etc continue parabolically. This could be more real-life like, but make for less fascinating reading in a book!The book, like real life, has many topics of a different kind meshed together. Some ideas are presented more succinctly and frequently in popular magazines/papers these days. As a result, the book contains few aha moments while many topics appear too commonplace in our world full of future-portraying tv serials and internet articles. The exceptions are when discussions move to a relatively distant future beyond 2050.Overall, interesting with many novel/fancy ideas in the long future sections but not path-breaking.

I didn't learn anything new, mainly because I've been a futurist fanboy my whole life. But it was a fun read mainly because the implicit message is "things are going to be All Right." One day soon, we will all live forever and have hovercars (not kidding).The last chapter, a day in the life of 2111, was hilarious. I have no idea where to begin. It reads exactly like a 1950s futurist's fantasy about, say, 2020. The author has never seen a technology he didn't like. I don't need to check if Michio Kaku is male; if he's female I will eat my smart-hat, complete with its mind-reading chips and biosensors. (Googles Michio Kaku) Oh, he's THAT guy - I see him on the Science channel all the time. I quite like him. He's the relentlessly cheerful "the oceans will boil" guy.Anyway, the author apparently doesn't see any possible downside in having tech companies monitor my every movement, every moment, down to my heartbeat and galvanic skin responses. For him, it's not about the tech companies, it's about the technology: I go pee in the morning and the technology monitors the effluent for signs of disease (or other things...). I say "book me a vacation" and the technology makes suggestions based on a few petabytes of my personal choices that I have willingly or unwittingly digitized and turned over to the corporations who own the tech. He has apparently never thought about the implications of total techno-surveillance. He imagines we will be free in our technological utopia. I, on the other hand, read his final chapter as a re-imagining of George Orwell's darkest fears.But again, I liked the book because it was a few hours of "everything's gonna be GREAT."

I gave this book three stars for the content and ideas it presented. Once they sink in--nanobots, nuclear fusion, genetic engineering, etc.--they truly are mindblowing. And to think they're being developed right now and might be ready in a few years! That said, my biggest issue is the editing (or lack thereof) of this book. It is unnecessarily long, repetitive in introductory sentences, and monotonous. I have to keep putting it down so the itch to take a red pen and just strikethrough some text passes. Also, there is no coherent threading from one chapter to the next, and while that may be a minor gripe, it does compound the problem.Also a problem (of sorts) is that this book was published in 2011 and I'm reading it in the year 2017, when Elon Musk (bless his soul) has already perfected the electric car and recovered and reused a Falcon 9 rocket. The six-year difference seemed like a whole century in scientific development, and some of the book's predictions now seem a little off by a few decades (i.e., Kaku predicted that by 2070 to 2100 we would have magnetic cars and trains, but one look at the progress on the Hyperloop says we might get there by 2030).Overall, this is a good gateway book to understanding all the strides being made in various fields of science right now. Just leave your inner editor at the door.

Listened to the audiobook, which was suitable for x2 speed but the narrator was a little monotonous. Closer to 3.5 stars.Overall an interesting, thinking person's book. The author regales us with numerous reasons why he's an expert on current technologies and thus able to accurately predict the future. He does follow up his bold claims with multiple interesting scenarios and technologies that are shaping the world now and how he sees the world unfolding in the next 100 years because of their influences. It's more or less segmented into topics like technology, medical applications, space travel, etc. The last chapter is written like a day in the life of a human in 2100, and was likely the most memorable (and least monotonous) section of the book. Fascinating, but it was just missing a little something-something.Favourite quotes:"Scientists now realize that forgetting may be as important as remembering in making sense of this world and organizing our knowledge.""The world's greatest contraceptive is prosperity... Science and technology are the engines of prosperity.""Walking in the Venusian surface, you would suffocate, be crushed to death, and your remains would be incinerated by the heat and dissolved by the sulphuric acid.""Science is organized knowledge. Wisdom is organized life." ~ Emanuel Kant

Alternately fascinating and depressing, Kaku takes us through a tour of where physics and science may take our world in the next 20 to 100 years. Written in 2011 so you get to check some of his 'near-term' predictions. The cheap sequencing of the human genome seems to be on schedule. The end of Moore's Law seems close, he suggested around 2020, the latest estimates hover around 2025. Biotechnology, nanotechnology, AI, computing, energy, medicine, space travel. It is all quite stunning and he regularly cites old Star Trek and Star Wars technologies that are already coming to pass or will soon. Makes you realize how revolutionary Star Trek really was! Kaku has generally a very optimistic attitude about human nature and an almost glib attitude to the possible impact of things like genetic engineering, hugely extended life spans, and AI. Maybe it will all work out very nicely like he seems to believe. Nothing will stop it, that much is certain unless a higher power intervenes. One thing seems certain, the rich will get much richer in ways that transcend money and are probably already happening. Whether all this wonderful change applies to the teeming masses seems dubious. Either way, this was a fascinating tour of the incredible impact of science and technology on how humans will live in years to come.

I genuinely thought I wasn't going to like this book for two reasons. 1.) I'm reading this book for summer reading ( it is a mandatory grade) and 2.) because it was about the future and all the technology of the future. Now I am not very much into the future and focusing on robots and different kinds of developing technologies; I barely even watch futuristic movies. However, Michio Kaku’s take on explaining what he and other leading researchers believed what was going to happen within the years 2012-2100 was absolutely fascinating. I have had this book glued to my side ever since I rented it from my town’s library and I am utterly amazed at how interesting it is. The book is a total of 368 pages, disregarding the starting chapter and sources pages, and it is divided into 9 main chapters with subchapters. The subchapters are the three time periods that Kaku divided up from 2012-2100, and the development of technologies as the chapters continue is astounding. As the story continues, I would become more ingrained in the book and was constantly wondering what technologies would be developed and how they would. This novel is a masterpiece and an absolute must read for futuristic technology lovers..

Physics of the future is a great book that allows you to take a peek into the future. It is a great book that allows you to know what type of inventions will be made and, how our lives will be changed. This book explores everything from space elevators made out of really strong material, artificial intelligence, space travel and different propulsion methods for space travel, medicine with tiny microscopic nanobots and many other technologies that might become a reality in the distant future. It warns us about the danger of global warming and Rising Waters. It tells how we might combat these issues from building giant dams to protect our most populated cities from rising waters and to using renewable sources for energy. The also book talks about what challenges are stopping us from making us more intelligent and how we can combat the challenges that limiting our current advancement. These challenges include needing to find a room temperature superconductor to the task of making space travel cheaper. It also talks about Mars and how we might colonize it one day. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who loves physics, technology, and, Science.

I am hard to please on this subject. I prefer more technical treatments on physics. This is not such a book. Nevertheless, the author won me over, probably because he was not speaking from his own point of view. He had interviewed other scientists and was presenting their views as well as his own. He did a good job at this and it added a lot of variety.Any problems? Like his previous books he tends to repeat himself. I recognized similar passages from his book "Parallel Words" and "The Physics of the Impossible". There were infrequent so their existence didn't pull me away from a general enjoyment of the book.The other problem occurred as he was wrapping up and extolling the virtues of science. While I agree that progress in society has been pushed along by scientific discovery, I disagree that science was the primary mover. In fact, some of the worst social disasters could have been avoided if we had all been a lot stupider. Nevertheless, I would not give up those scientific advances just to avoid those social disasters. Such things cannot be avoided by stopping the advance of science. They can only be delayed.I'd read this book again.

TL;DR - gives some interesting thoughts on how technology will advance and change society up until the year 2100.An informative read that is worth your time if you are curious about how technology and civilization will advance throughout the rest of this century. While we never truly can know what will happen in the future, this book does offer many possible and interesting theories. And if you're worried this will be a dry, technical read - I didn't find this to be the case. Some details get very technical, but I didn't find it overwhelming to where I couldn't understand the basic concepts.Only real nitpicking is that it's called "physics of the future" and is marketed to discuss mostly technology but it does cover some other future topics such as economics and politics briefly as well. Which is understandable, as future technology will certainly impact them - just worth noting as those sections read a bit differently and may not fit your taste if you were purely interested in the technology side of things. Also, there are a few times where the author is a bit repetitive but it's not worth a serious complaint - just a minor nitpick.

a bit of a slog to get through. some repetitive sentences (like the gods of mythology...) but I liked the pop culture references. liked how he tried to measure his predictions against some criteria (be in development now, not break the laws of physics, etc) guessing that far into the future is as much about social and economic predictions as technological. so some of it might be slower than predicted. Guess it was published in 2011 or 2012 as no studies are later than 2010, so he mentions Tesla in passing but not SpaceX. fun ideas though. seems to get the physics behind most of it as well as the institutional bias that are inherent in some fields (the most AI researchers are physicists and have the same worldview) the last few chapters are where I feel it was weakest. but the falling behind academically in the west thing is a bit scary even though he tempered it with the west being more creative. how do I develop both in my kids?

This was the first book I read on science. It completely blew my mind off!Not only does Kaku tackle complicate matters in easy words, he also explains his world view in a very refreshing way. From economics to human nature, his views are so unexpected to me that pretty much everything made an impression on me. It is like my brain has been rewired just by reading this book.Another aspect of this book is the amount of optimism it carries along. Even though some technical developments appear scary and threatening, even though some possible scenarios mentioned into the book can be downright frightening, one cannot close this book with a feeling that nothing can be done. It is in fact the opposite. I now feel like there is nothing the future cannot grant and nothing cannot be done anymore.Hope Kaku will write more on the subject and be translated in more languages! We need such books to be spread.

This is a very ambitious and charming project and Kaku handled it really well. It is a bit leaning too much over physics, but for the other parts, it is highly informative without being neither too technical nor too simplifying. For me, the quality check was how he handled my area, tissue engineering. It was factual, easy to understand; he missed some subtleties but that is normal and the people he picked to talk with are very good choices too. So, if I extrapolate that to the rest of the book; it is safe to say that it gives a reasonable snapshot of what is to come. It is slightly naive in its treatment of certain social and economical ramifications and has this golden age sci-fi overt-optimism to it, but I find that cute also. The only criticism I have is that it kinda omitted chemistry (it can be said that nanotechnology parts are chemistry, but they were not treated like that), where some amazing stuff is happening. It was my first Kaku book, I will read his others for sure.

The author quite clearly explained his vision of a possible future for the planet. Much of the science includes ideas and innovations about which I had already read, but he skillfully integrated much of what is happening in research and development into a startling potential reality. It all sounds quite remarkable. But I don't believe the transition from a 0.7 civilization to a 1.o planetary civilization will be as smooth as we hope. And even if we manage to attain it without destroying the environment and each other, we will still not have addressed human nature and selfishness. Even in a 1.0 civilization (as in the Star Trek universe the author references), people will still be greedy, envious, and power-hungry. Will it be possible to engineer our descendants genes to remove negative behavioral and personality traits?

This is a really fascinating book talking about future technologies that very well may be real life within the next century. This book is similar to his "Physics of the Impossible", but the technologies he is talking about here are ones that are actually being researched and created now, albeit in their rudimentary stages. In their respective chapters he talks about the future of computers, AI, medicine, energy, space travel, nanotechnology, and my personal favorite, wealth. The wealth chapter focuses on how our world may run in the next century when it comes to economics. He seems very optimistic about most of these ideas, but he does write how we may have a difficult time transitioning into a Type 1 civilization, as we are still plagued with greed, bigotry, and class systems. It will be interesting to see what becomes of these great leaps in technology.

This is a really interesting survey of where technology may take us in the next 100 years. The author breaks it down into several components, healthcare vs. space vs. transportation, and talks about current developments, medium term potential and where we might get to by 2100. It's a very thoughtful approach in many ways and easy to follow. His ability to distill complex topics is quite good making this an accessible book even for the person afraid of science.The only thing that stood out to me was his review of computers. In many cases he applies the logic of exponential progress and how things might evolve in amazing ways. For some reason in computing he sort of lets current physical silicon limitations dictate without going to where quantum computing or other technologies might take us in this realm. But apart from that it was a really excellent book.

This was a quick, fun read, and it made me check to see when it was published because some of Kaku's predictions for the near and distant future are already under way! Because I love to read brain books, I knew about how we're already figuring out how to "read" particular thoughts. There's a ways to go (see Kaku's discussions of how lame robots are at navigating obstacles because they're not the pattern recognition pros we are), but interpreting basic commands is already nearly there.I do think he's a little hopeful about humanity rising entirely above infighting and reaching the look-how-scientific-advances-have-helped-us-all-get-along-! within the near future, but I have a fairly bleak view of human nature. I'd love to be wrong. But who cares? I'll be dead. Hope my great-grandkids enjoy the post-electric world and using their unreproducible creativity.

This was an absolutely fascinating read for most of it. The chapters on advances in computing, medicine, and energy were precious. Two gripes: 1.) The author let out a lot of steam with the discussion about advances in space. Sure, it seemed interesting but I kept on thinking one question throughout the chapter: "To what end?" What is the purpose of pushing to travel to other planets or worlds? Oh well -- just a small gripe. The entire chapter on space fell desperately short, especially comparing to the rest of the material. 2.) I felt the concluding chapter was thoroughly boring. I understand the purpose behind it -- but it let out even more steam. Otherwise, the rest of the book was captivating. I still highly recommend it to anyone. I'm even encouraging my 10 yr old to read it.

One part Kurzweil's The Singularity is Near, and one part Pinker's Enlightenment Now, the author combines observations and interviews with scientists and authors to sketch out a forecast of the next 100 years. He intones repeatedly that science is the engine of progress and lays out many examples to show how innovative have had cascading effects driving other innovations. At the same time, we are influenced by "the caveman principle, " that our personalities and motivations have not changed much over the past 100,000 years even though we live longer, healthier and wealthier lives. Humans will have to overcome old patterns of belief if we are to achieve the type of sustainable civilization that the fruits of technology make possible. It was a fun read, and now that the book has been about a decade it is possible to check our progress adjust our course to keep the goal in sight.

This brought to mind when I constructed helicopters or whatever you made from toilet paper rolls for the Olympiad in a constricted time frame. It's a good story. I think you might like it.It feels like almost everything I read centers around the same few themes, concepts and principles, even if I try to go all around the library far and wide, and even to different libraries, or even to buy books from elsewhere. Is it that I am only interested in those couple topics? OH, maybe it's that I determined beforehand those were the "safe" ones that wouldn't make me have panic attacks. Maybe next time I'll read something about dinosaurs. Okay that's Dewey Decimal 567.This one talks about chemical engineering in a way I wasn't too clear about, so you might be able to pick up on that if you're one of those sorts!

Dr. Michio Kaku has done more to enlighten the masses, to expand our minds, than any other academic in his field in history, bar none. As with his talks and lectures, in this read he enthralls with his highly educated predictions for humanity by the dawn of the next century and he does so in a way that only Professor Kaku can do - with wit and charm and and an oh so pleasing demeanor to his written words. Be you a fan of the man or someone curious about what science might have in store for our species ... what wonders your children and grandchildren and great grandchildren might experience in their lifetimes that are only dreams and imaginations today, then prepare yourself to take a genuinely possible trip into the future that only Dr. Kaku can take you on with such aplomb. This is a thoroughly enjoyable read.

Physics of the Future is a speculative nonfiction book by renowned physicist Michio Kaku that offers an interesting perspective of what the near future looks like for humans.The word "physics" in the title may turn some people off but it's a surprisingly tame book. I finished it in 5 days. Many of the chapters begin with tales from Norse and Greek mythology that illustrates the technology explained in that chapter. There are some scientific terminology spread across some pages, but they're used sparingly and I never felt left out.If there's a gripe that I have for this book is that coming from a third-world country the speculated technologies mentioned in this book may not be coming to my neighborhood when it actually comes out!

This is a fun read for techies and fantasising about how science and technology could unfold in the not too distant future. Some of the ideas seem outragous, like the space elevator, but it's interesting to note that some other ideas are already very easily acheiveable, like the talking walls which is essentially Apple's Siri or Google Now. So it's not unreasonable to imagine how the crazier ideas could soon come to be a reality. He seems to predict science and technology will be the saviour of all humanity, and there's an overly keen aspiration that humans will become gods. Nonetheless it does make you believe so much technological advance is tantalisingly close and you kind of get to see how it might work.Verdict: Infused with fun ideas and game changing advances, there's a constant running theme that science and technology will eventually solve all of the world's major problems. A great read, though overly obsessed with humans becoming gods. The last chapter on a day in the life of 2100 is fun.#2017readingchallenge

I like this book. Probably because I am interested in the future of tech and have yet to read a book that explores it other than this one, so my opinion will probably changeA great way of summarising the inevitable technologies of the near future, however that's all it is - a summary. Would have been nice to learn more these technologies with even slightly more detail.May be even out-dated to an extent today as advances have been made since writing and new techs have emerged but a definite must read for learning about the future of science in general.However, this book had very little to do with physics which is misleading and disappointing. Would have been nice to learn about the *physics* behind these technologies.I do love the cover of this edition though.....

paints a very colorful picture for every segment of life and science that is going to be relevant now, in the near and in the far future. all based on research happening in laboratories now. basically sci-fi without much fiction. yet stifled by a lot.of hyperbole and blunt assumptions without facts or calculations. it is a good foundation for the not-so-tech-savvy, getting an idea what research is actually done today, but everything that is his imagination of the future has to be taken with a grain of salt. no one can be an oracle, but least so when done with so much disregard for human tendencies and current development. still good food for thought. (plus what is it with him wanting us to be gods all the time?)

I am now on my fourth Michio Kaku book, and they're getting kind of repetitive. It feels sort of like this was ghost-written, given a few wording errors when discussing basic science -- mistakes I don't feel like Dr. Kaku would have made. Regardless, he's basically covering most of the same technologies that he covered in Physics of the Impossible and The Future of Humanity.Another significant problem, here and in prior books, is that Kaku is not a social scientist, but he often attempts to be. His social science is terrible. He relies on wide-eyed speculation that is thoroughly tone-deaf to issues of class, race, colonialism, imperialism, and gender politics.Nonetheless, I've enjoyed his books, even if I take his speculations with a grain of salt.

Fun review of current physics research and how it might play out going forward. But the author's one-dimensional idealistic naivety about how software and culture work require the reader to discount the predictions. For example, he dismisses the potential for state governments to become technical big brothers. (The book was written before China advanced the frontier of possibility in technical-enabled autocracy.) He thinks a simple "kill switch" on robots will allow humans to shut down AI/bots run amok with a simple command. He believes we'll have stopped fighting within 100 years, and will have abolished territorial nation-state territorial disputes, etc. Felt shallow and pat and not at all connected to deeper thought in political science, technology, etc.

Just okay. I picked this up for a few dollars at a used bookstore, thinking I would use it as a sort of a quick reference as I read or write future-set stories. It does help sort technologies into how quickly they will (probably) come to pass before 2100, from near future to midcentury to far future. This book can't offer more than a quick survey of each topic, and if you want more in-depth information you'll have to seek out other sources. The more science-focused earlier chapters are the best, but once Kaku gets outside his expertise and starts trying to make predictions on humanity, wealth, politics, etc. things kind of go off the rails. Some of the book is also outdated, given that it was published in 2011, but that's not the book's fault.

Basically, it’s an interesting book to read, but I had another edition, where there’s 702 pages, and somewhere in the middle I got so bored. We can sum up everything that he said on the last 30% of his book as - “We don’t have any f*cking money, but if we do, it would be great to have this and that”. It’s quite captivating at the beginning with the variety of suggestions about the future, but it can be clearly seen that it was written by a scientist. There were no place for predictions about people’s reaction, when they would know that everything is being checked by a Big brother. So, if he were working with a sociologist, it would be a perfect work, but for now, he’s talking about the future partially.

My biggest takeaway: innovation follows some macro-scale patterns. I love to see macro-scale patterns. I had the blissful good fortune that I consumed this book via audiobook while reading a paperback copy of “Empires of Light” by Jill Jonnes. Michio Katy’s book actually overwhelmed me at certain points but together with “Empires” brought me a fascinating perspective about the inevitability of technological progress. “Physics of the Future” made me roundly uncomfortable due to sheer scope of the coming technological advancements. “Empires” showed me that I feel much like everyone in the 1890’s felt when electricity entered their lives. If it’s scary, then it’s roller coaster scary, not cancer scary.

Fantastic, insightful look into how technological evolution projects into the next century. It's amazing that many of these things may be less than 100 years away, but then when we look back at the last 100 years, and the 100 years before that, it's hard to rule it out. Some parts sagged a bit in terms of how interesting the content is, but overall, this is an incredibly well-researched and fascinating book. I love that it closes the last few chapters by peering backward in human history to highlight key lessons that are critical for society to learn from in order to tackle the challenges ahead!

Rating: 4.25 starsThis was a lengthy one. It's like a chocolate cheesecake. Consuming ot in small frequent doses is best =) This book discusses science from its historical use to its future implementation in daily life. It's great for science geeks and peeps who want to get a broader grasp on physics. It's downfall is it's publication date (this is a science book therefore the moment it goes into print it's already outdated to some extent) and the excessive facts spewed at a mind numbing rate. However, like I said just treat it like chocolate cheesecake and it's a good book! The audiobook is a better option in my opinion.

I didn't like the constant comparisons to Greek mythology, but overall I enjoyed the book. The book was good for getting the imagination to run. I didn't agree with all the possibilities Kaku presented, but the ideas were interesting. Personally I felt in some ways he both underestimated the growth of technology in some parts as well as overestimated it in others.I agree with other reviewers in that the title is misleading and the book doesn't deal terribly much with physics. I don't find it much of a big deal since I read the book blurb before purchasing and knew what to expect.More on AI and transhumanism might have bumped it up to a five star book for me.

author is so busy making claims about what will be that he forgets to ask himself "would people even want this?". the amount of stuff he claims will be commonplace that I would absolutely not want nor purchase is crazy. almost everything he talks about is something I had no interest in. He makes no attempt to explain how anything is possible, he loop holes it by explaining the rapid growth of tech in the past couple decades and then having you assume it will continue that trend resulting in all his claims.The writing sucks, the narrator of the audio book sucks worse.What a terrible book

I have to admit that I wound up skimming through a couple of chapters. I loved the introduction so I couldn't wait to read more. Some of the book was fascinating and some of it was terrifying. Some of the things he wrote about that may happen in the future seemed a little bizarre and far fetched even for two-hundred years from now. I liked the way he wrote about the past, (the Middle Ages for example), and how the world could one day wake up and find that it has been pushed back a few hundred-years. I'm currently reading The Future of Humanity by Michio Kaku, so far I like this one even better.

A nicely written realistic prognosis of the future of Humanity that covers the role technology will play in shaping our lives in this century and early next century. Many of its predictions have already come to pass since this book was published in 2011. Some of the predictions sound superfluous to the common mind but are actually well thought out. The downside of the book is that the author keeps repeating himself several times. Perhaps that shows his excitement or it's a technique to buttress his points. It however is a partial eyesore. Despite this, I give this book a high rating and I recommend it for anyone who wants to have a glimpse of our common future in the universe.

There is quite a lot of hard science that is delivered through somewhat accessible language and I give kudos to the author and editor. I read Visions and is quite convinced that Michio Kaku can definitely tell us what the future of the world will be like through technology and the eventual plateau of it. I would have like more insights on the socio effects and it's a nice touch to actually read about Singapore in this book. I would say living in 2100 is not much different from living in 2050, only that we have access to space, harness alternative energies, living longer and customising the future generation - this is the dangerous part.

Fun and informative. A 10-year-old book of future predictions had me totally entertained. As I read, I looked up many of the topics to see whether the predictions were on track. Sadly, many of the space programs mentioned in the near future sections have been cancelled, but many others seem to be progressing as forecast.Video clips of Michio Kaku have circulated on social media discussing our "Type 0 Civilization" status. This topic is discussed in some detail on the book and is so relevant now as we see culture clashes over the pandemic response. The Cave Man Principle is useful for making sense of the current world.Overall, I quite enjoyed the book and recommend it.

Well worth a read if interested in futureologyComputers will become ubiquitousAugmented realityGenetic science and virtual doctors will make diseases a thing of the pastStem-cell technology will increase lifespansAnother way to extend our lifespans could be achieved by switching off certain genes which are responsible for aging.New sources of transport will save energy and revolutionize transport Superconductors could harness the power of magnetism to build very efficient ways of transportation. Telekinetic technology will allow us to move objects with our thoughtsArtificial Intelligence will solve many of our problemshttps://www.karlbooklover.com/physics...

I loved this book! I want to live to 2100 just so I can see all of this come true. The only thing I didn't like was, in the last chapter, the author portrayed what could be a typical day for a business man. He had a meeting with his board, some of whom were there as holograms only visible if you had on the glasses. My problem with this is he's speaking to board members who are all men. In 2100. Really? There couldn't have been some women in his scenario? This was the only part of the book that rubbed me the wrong way.

Considering that the book was written in 2011, it's already in the past. However, most of Kaku's predictions are about to become reality.Kaku talked about true AI and gave the example of Honda's ASIMO robot. Today we have Sofia, a robot that can have a conversation with human. It can think, make a decision about what to say next, phrase a sentence and speak it.The same is true about other things that Kaku predicted such as wearable devices, health trackers, brain interfaces etc.Nevertheless, it was a good read.

4.5/10I had high hopes butwas disappointed with this book. A lot of it sounded like my out of touch college professors trying to sound like they have a good grasp on what is going on today by taking one potential technological breakthrough then telling me how it's going to change the world.Near the end he gets to his specialty which is physics rather than technology and the last 1/4 of the book is pretty good, but overall is say skip this one. If you're looking for a good futurist book, the author's Future of Humanity is MUCH better

Really incredible book packed full of rare facts and future predictions. Michio Kaku is a master at simplifying complex scientific theories into easy-to-digest passages for the lay reader. He covered many areas, especially nanotechnology, biotechnology, and telecommunications. The narrative set in the future, though a bit cheesy at times, illustrated just how different life can be by the year 2100. For anyone who is interested in the trajectory of science and the current progress of mankind, this is an ideal read.

Michio Kaku writes a very well detailed conjecture that is engrossing. Can be a bit intensive for some people because of the amount of information but it is well laid out in a simple way while maintaining an impressive flow. Must read for any one with a scientific/futuristic temperament. (Additional tip - Pretty interesting evidence-backed source for writers who want a little help with good ideas for sci-fi worldbuilding.)

The book is a huge source of kind of up too date research references. It's amazing and impressive. From one side a lot of sounds futuristic from the other some aspects are totally old fashioned. It's very nice to see disruptions in energy, electric cars, VR/AR and AI that already happened through were predicted in 2030-2010 :) Physics is definitely fuels innovation, yet impossible challenges fuels inspiration :)

We read this book as a jigsaw. While my classmates read and presented on other chapters, I focused on Chapter 5, "Future of Energy: Energy from the Stars". All the chapters discuss the cutting-edge technology that Kaku predicted in 2011, most of which is currently happening. From solar energy to driverless cars to AI, he outlines the positive and potentially negative outcomes of these advancements.

I was kind of lost by some of the physics, but on the whole a very clear and succinct 'map' of major changes by area (e.g., energy or civilization) broken out by present to 2030, 2030-2070, and then 2070 to 2100. Also, largely optimistic which, I mean, future prediction (flying cars!) often turn out to be silly, but a nice change from most of these books which make you want to run for a spaceship.

More like "technology of the future" than "physics", this expands on sections of Kaku's previous book "Physics of the Impossible" by extrapolating into the future what our current technology and our understanding could accomplish. Nanobots, chips everywhere, interstellar exploration via nano-swarms, and of course our robot overlords. A pretty easy read with some ideas that make you think about what the coming years could be like.

"By 2100, our destiny is to become like the gods we once worshipped and feared. But our tools will not be magic wands and potions but the science of computers, nanotechnology, artificial intelligence, biotechnology, and most of all, the quantum theory."Very, very interesting read about the potential future of science in our world over the next 100 years. Michio Kaku presents information that is (almost always) easy to understand even for people who are not physicists.

I find the book not well strcutured. There is also many repetitive sentances which you want to skip while reading the book. There are some interesting facts inside the book. What i like the most is the comparision how people saw today's achievements in their time.One thing i still cannot understand is why all astronomers are aiming to fertilize Mars spending billions of dollars, but leave Earth's deserts aside.

I read this book in 2014 and found it very interesting and mostly easy to read. I would recommend it to anyone interested in measured predictions about where human life is heading from a scientific perspective. You don't have to be a scientist in any way to easily access the ideas in this book so don't be put off by the word 'Physics' in the title!The chapter on AI and consciousness I found particularly interesting and has stuck with me.

Very good with flaws. Strengths: - Creates vision for the future of humanity. From there on you can assess on your own what's realistic and what not. - Techno-optimistic but reflected on the fact that technology also can be harmful. - Easy-to-read. Weaknesses: - Sometimes too bold and overly simplistic about its assumptions and outlooks but it is okay as long as you do not expect "in detail future scenario modelling"

This was an interesting read; however, for someone who is a semi-informed science enthusiast there were few topics in the book that I hadn't encountered in news articles over the past 8 years or so. That's the major drawback to writing a book about cutting-edge science- it's out of date by the time it's published. Still, not a bad book particularly for readers who don't follow regular science publications.

- written in 2011, this was an interesting science based look at what technologies may revolutionize the next century. I think he most greatly underestimated the growth of AI, even in the past decade. My favorite part was his discussion of how we might explore the universe with molecule size spaceships... it didn’t address how we’ll get data back, but I guess we need to be surprised by something...

I skimmed through this, there wasn't a lot of tremendous insight in the book, but seems to be a fairly dry look from a technologist's point of view (this is a book about technology not physics). Actually it's all about technology. So that part of his predictions may be reasonable but his predictions about culture and politics were through rose-colored AR contact lenses. I did like the space chapter though, probably because it's mostly science fiction.

Kaku is a well regarded theoretical physicist (think Sheldon Cooper from Big Bang Theory!) in the science field and this 2011 release makes the case for future technology advancements based on the history and current trends in specific fields to include computers, artificial intelligence, medicine, nanotechnology, energy, space travel, wealth and humanity writ large. A very readable and thoroughly researched book that sparks innovative imagination!

Kaku gives some insight about the possibility of future advances in technology, but the writing leaves a bit to be desired. He talks about existing technology and how those might change over time and references popular sci-fi technologies, such as those of Star Trek and writes about how technology might advance in the coming years. The ideas are more of a general picture rather than how we achieve these advances in specific steps.

What will technology bring over the next several decades? From magically controlling our physical environments with our thoughts to clothing that tracks our vitals and nano-probes exploring the far reaches of space, Kaku lays out the basis for a technological wonderland only a few years out. And it’s all based on technologies that are already being developed. Published 9 years ago in March 2011, the predictions so far have held up well.

Life in 2100 is basically going to be the 1990 Arnold movie- Total Recall. But on a serious note, there are some cool ideas coming down the pipeline and any opportunity to reference sci fi in a non-ironic way is pure gold. Since I’m 10 years late reading this, I was want to point out the irony of his huge miss in the intro/1st chapter. All that stuff just happened because of a global pandemic.... so, I’ll forgive that oversight. The rest is totally likely.

The exploration of content was interesting, but I wanted more out of it. It often felt like Kaku breezed over many of the dependencies for his predictions, leaving the book feeling like his wishlist for the far future. Interesting read, but any kind of approachable depth to the subject would have been better.

Despite the name, there wasn't much of actual physics involved. It's more like "Technology of the future that you already knew about". There weren't much discoveries in this book. I was expecting to get some insight into how physics will actually change the world. Instead, it's just him talking about how he gets to try all these cool technologies we read about in the news as a renown scientist and how much they will improve in the future. And well...how we'll be God.

I wish I've read this book earlier. It explains main scientific progressions affecting humans' destiny. Things we take for granted now are based on decades of scientific endeavor. To predict the future, we have to know the history. Recommend this book if you want to know the physics history of last century and how it will shape our future.

A fun and informative jaunt through the next century of technological innovation. Kaku's book was written in 2011 and it is amazing how in 6 years, already some of his predictions are either coming to fruition or being trumped by an unforeseen innovation. The next century will indeed be the turning point in human civilization.

First DNF of the 2018 year. For the right reader, this book is probably very engaging. I find it tedious and repetitive. Some people really enjoy worrying about whether robots will be running humans in the future and while I think some rogue robots may occur, it seems turning them off is still a fine option.

It may look like one of those popular future prediction books but Michio Kaku has written this book to make you ask some questions on what we have today and how it may evolve in the near future (30 years period) and far future (100 years period). I like the way of his explanation on the things we define 'impossible to be' can actually exist in the future. Highly recommended.

The view of the future is neat, however the whole "gods of mythology" thing gets really annoying really fast. On top of that, sections can really drag on. Chapter 2 is really the worst offender, and it seems less factual than the rest. Overall however, I'd recommend it to people who want to see what the future may hold.

Kaku it is undoubtedly a brilliant man, but this does not necessarily make him a good author. There are a few instances where he delves deeper into a topic, and this is where the book is most interesting. Unfortunately, many of the topics only receive a superficial discussion. The book is very accessible, so much so, that it feels dumbed-down and incomplete.
